TITLE I--RETAILER INTEGRITY

Authority to establish authorization periods for accepting and redeeming coupons under the Food Stamp Program. The Secretary can issue regulations setting specific time periods for authorization validity. Additionally, specific periods can be established for stores prohibited from participating based on lack of business integrity. Stores with denied or withdrawn approval based on business integrity and reputation cannot reapply for approval for a set period reflecting the severity of the infractions. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include requirements for submitting relevant income and tax documents for eligibility verification. Retail food stores may need to provide written authorization for tax filing verification. Additionally, regulations may establish a waiting period for stores that initially fail to meet authorization criteria. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include a waiting period for stores that fail to meet authorization criteria. Retail food stores or wholesale food concerns are prohibited from submitting a new application for six months if their initial application is denied. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 now includes criteria for suspensions and disqualifications of retail food stores or wholesale food concerns based on evidence such as on-site investigations and inconsistent redemption data. Additionally, stores violating program requirements can be suspended pending administrative and judicial review. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 allows for the suspension of retail food stores or wholesale food concerns found to have violated program requirements. The Secretary is not liable for any lost sales during suspension or disqualification periods. Amendments also include provisions for suspensions in Section 14 of the Act. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 allows for the suspension of retail food stores or wholesale food concerns for violations. Suspensions remain in effect during review processes and are considered part of any disqualification period. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 allows for the disqualification of retailers who are disqualified from the WIC program. The Secretary will issue regulations for this disqualification, which will be for the same period as the disqualification from the WIC Program and may not be subject to review. Additionally, retailers who intentionally submit falsified applications may face permanent debarment. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 allows for permanent debarment of retailers who intentionally submit falsified applications. Additionally, there will be expanded civil and criminal forfeiture for violations of the food stamp act. Sec. 109 of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 amends provisions for forfeiture of items involved in food stamp trafficking and introduces civil forfeiture for violations involving food stamp benefits valued at $5,000 or more. The amendment also extends civil forfeiture laws to seizures related to these violations. Civil forfeitures now apply to seizures or forfeitures related to violations involving food stamp benefits valued at $5,000 or more. Any person convicted of such violations must forfeit the benefits, property obtained from the violation, and property used to commit the violation to the United States. The court must order the forfeiture of all property related to violations involving food stamp benefits valued at $5,000 or more to the United States. The rules and regulations necessary for this subsection will be prescribed by the Secretary. Expanded authority for sharing information provided by retailers. Sec. 110 amends the Social Security Act and Internal Revenue Code to include State government officers and agencies responsible for WIC in information sharing. The Administrative Reform Act of 1994 is amended to include State government officers and agencies responsible for administering the WIC program in information sharing. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include expanded definitions of coupons and doubled penalties for violating program requirements. Mandatory claims collection methods are also introduced. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include expanded definitions of coupons and doubled penalties for violating program requirements. Mandatory claims collection methods are also introduced, including refunds of Federal taxes as authorized by 31 U.S.C. 3720A. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include officers, employees, or agents, including State agencies. These provisions are effective from October 1, 1995. Implementation and effective dates of the provisions in the Act will be on the date of enactment.
